doom.driver: Russia targets Ukraine with 345 drones and missiles, Zelenskyy says.
doom.blurb: RUSSIA TURNS UP THE DIAL TO 345
doom.summary: Russia just launched 345 drones and missiles at Ukraine in a single night, which is either a negotiating tactic or proof that 'ceasefire talks' is a phrase that means nothing. Meanwhile Zelensky is telling the BBC this is already World War 3, which tracks, and Iran still hasn't 'capitulated' despite Trump's evident puzzlement — apparently maximum pressure works on a different schedule than Mar-a-Lago expects. El Mencho is dead, cartel violence is exploding in tourist zones, and someone brought a shotgun and a fuel can to Trump's front door. Cheerful Monday.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: A 345-drone-and-missile barrage on Ukraine signals Russia escalating rather than moderating, while Zelensky publicly declares WW3 is already underway.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: TSA PreCheck was suspended then un-suspended in hours, a perfect symbol of a government operating on vibes — meanwhile Trump is still baffled Iran hasn't folded.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: Perplexity joins Galaxy AI and researchers are hiding backdoors in 40MB binaries to test AI detection — useful stress test, not a doom signal.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: El Mencho's death has already triggered burnt vehicles and resort lockdowns in Puerto Vallarta; cartel succession violence is historically unpredictable and rapid.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: Al Jazeera notes that AI alarm cycles produce 'lots of talk, little action' — the meta-commentary is bleak but the underlying systems aren't notably more dangerous today.

doom.dalle_prompt: Pixel art, 16-bit SNES style, weather-dominated scene — a bitter pre-dawn winter night over the flat suburban landscape of Kyiv Oblast, a dense overcast sky pressing down like a lid of charcoal and slate, freezing fog diffusing every light source into ghostly smeared halos, the air itself thick with cold haze and drifting smoke that bleeds deep navy into smoldering orange at the edges. The scene is filtered through this atmospheric murk: a low-rise residential neighborhood of Soviet-era single-family homes with pitched roofs and bare winter trees standing skeletal against the darkness, a collapsed house in the middle distance with its roof caved inward, exposed interior walls showing pale wallpaper and tumbled timber, a debris field of frozen brick spreading across frost-hardened mud. Above the rooftops, the overcast clouds are lit from below by a distant orange glow — an apartment building upper floor burning, flames pushing through blown-out windows, a heavy black smoke column rising and folding into the fog layer. High overhead in the haze-filtered sky, dozens of small delta-wing silhouettes drift in irregular patterns, their faint propeller exhausts leaving tiny orange pinpoints dissolving into the murk. Upward-streaking interceptor missile trails cut bright white scratches through the navy darkness before vanishing into cloud. A damaged Orthodox church with a cracked onion dome is barely visible in the far background, its golden surface dulled to amber by smoke. Deep navy and smoldering orange dominate everything, warmth feels threatening, heavy shadows swallow the foreground, no text, no antialiasing.

dawn.driver: Golden again! U.S. tops Canada to win 1st men's hockey gold since 'Miracle on Ice'. The U.S. won its first Olympic gold in 46 years in a 2-1 overtime thriller over rival Canada. A brilliant performance by U.S. goaltender Connor Hellebuyck saved the Americans' chances.
dawn.summary: In a world thick with geopolitical tension and conflict, two neighboring nations settled their rivalry the best possible way — on ice, in overtime, with everything on the line. The U.S. men's hockey team's first Olympic gold since the legendary 1980 Miracle on Ice is a reminder that human beings can still produce moments of pure, shared awe. Connor Hellebuyck's miraculous saves and the overtime drama gave millions something uncomplicated to cheer about — and that matters more than it sounds.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: A 46-year wait ended in overtime gold, proving that patience, grit, and belief in the impossible still pay off.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: The Olympics itself — nations gathering to compete peacefully — continues to function as a rare arena of constructive international engagement.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: Evidence of the bouba-kiki effect in baby chicks suggests cross-species roots to language perception, a quietly fascinating discovery about the nature of mind.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: Syria's evacuation of the al-Hol desert camp — long a humanitarian pressure point — marks a small but real step toward stabilization in a ravaged region.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Yoga classes bringing moments of calm to traumatised children in Gaza show that human compassion persists even inside the most brutal circumstances.

dawn.dalle_prompt: Pixel art, 16-bit SNES style, extreme close-up filling the entire frame with a single gold Olympic medal viewed at a dramatic side angle, the medal face catching intense arena light and radiating deep amber and warm teal reflections, the ribbon draped in red white and blue fabric folding at the edges of the frame, the medal surface engraved with the Milano Cortina 2026 five-ring emblem glowing as if lit from within, the polished gold disc reflecting a ghostly distorted miniature of a packed arena crowd visible in its curved surface, blurred streaks of American flag red and white caught in the reflection, the faint suggestion of a goaltender's masked silhouette and raised arms mirrored in the medal's gleaming face, the ribbon edge showing worn fabric from battle-worn celebration, harsh overhead arena whites warming to radiant golden amber across the entire medal surface, long side-cast shadows falling across the ribbon folds, no text, no antialiasing, extreme close-up, frame entirely filled
